text: pear chips you've probably seen at the
grocery store but they're so easy to
make and far cheaper if you do them at
home you can use any variety here this
is a red Anjou I also have a green Anjou
and a Taylor Gold but any variety that
you like will work be sure to choose a
firm but ripe pear and the easiest way
to check is the old sniff test should
have a little fragrance there that's
nice you can also use a mandolin if
you're not comfortable with a knife
these things are very sharp do be
careful but it does make quick work of
something like this and these do come
with a guard if you want to use that but
you can see how much faster that is than
a knife and these go on to a parchment
lined baking sheet before heading for
the oven you can see that I didn't core
these peel these or anything if you do
have a seed just pop that out quickly
you definitely don't want to eat that
looks like one pair is gonna be enough
to fill a tray I even like to leave the
stem on it makes for a really pretty
presentation when it comes out they're
absolutely delicious plain but you can
also jazz them up a little bit with
cinnamon sugar or maple syrup I think
the rest of these I'm gonna give maple
syrup be generous it takes it more than
you think
maple is nice because it really brings
out those fall flavors these are gonna
dehydrate in a 225 degree oven for about
three hours flip them halfway through
and you'll know they're done when the
edges start to curl but the parish
should still be pliable our pear types
are cool and crisp as you can see and
these are so delicious with a French
triple cream and toasted pecans this
makes for a really elegant presentation
and I like to serve this with champagne
that's when you know it's a party these
thin crispy pear chips eaten with a soft
gooey cheese and toasted pecans they're
absolutely irresistible and you won't be
able to stop I promise
you
